title: Importing new blocks takes a very long time (~1m)
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `geth version`
1.9.25-stable
OS & Version: Windows/Linux/OSX
linux
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour

geth syncs the block within a couple ms

#### Actual behaviour

geth takes longer than expected to import (30s-1m)

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

run geth normally

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````

I am using a raspberry pi 4, 8gb of ram, and my cpu is not being pinned. I did the initial sync up to chain head on another desktop pc, then upon bringing it on the raspberry pi, I can't manage to import the ~100 blocks that were added to chain head while I was moving the storage. My ssd is quick enough too.

+1
I have met with very slow synchronization recently (geth v1.9.25)
the average syncing speed is far slower than the speed that new blocks are mined
So I've got about 4700 blocks delay until now
But the I had been able to keep up with the latest block for the last 8 months
this is the logs I got for geth:

INFO [02-16|13:57:56.903] Deep froze chain segment                 blocks=15 elapsed=1.094s     number=11773541 hash="1561f0…056960"**

How can I fix this ? Or how can I debug on this?
Based on your logs, you have Geth 1GB of cache allowance in total. That won't be enough for a mainnet node.

hey @karalabe and @Muggle-Du! I was using a raspberry pi and my storage was an external ssd which was formatted (and originally synced with) a NTFS filesystem, which runs very slow on linux. I formatted it into ext4 and started syncing again and no longer slow.

> Based on your logs, you have Geth 1GB of cache allowance in total. That won't be enough for a mainnet node.

Thanks, I'll set 4096 for cache . 
By the way, what does "dirty " in the logs mean

> > Based on your logs, you have Geth 1GB of cache allowance in total. That won't be enough for a mainnet node.
> 
> Thanks, I'll set 4096 for cache .
> By the way, what does "dirty " in the logs mean

And after I restarted the geth with "--cache 4096", the syncing speed didn't get improved

@Muggle-Du what os are you on? what cpu do you have? what storage do you have?
It takes a while for caches to get loaded with data.

> @Muggle-Du what os are you on? what cpu do you have? what storage do you have?

system info: Ubuntu 18
cpu: 64 cores server cpu 
Memory: 252G
storage: 10T SSD
is your io slow? what filesystem is your ssd formatted with

@Muggle-Du I'll close this issue for now. If you're still experience these long import times, please open a new issue!
Thanks @TennisBowling for reporting that execution speed increased when switching from NTFS to Ext4
